episodes.original_body:
Case: Michael-Johnston-WC-05-03-2023
Client: Michael Johnston

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Spoke to client today. He is back at same job full time. No TTDs unpaid to date. Still has some unresolved issues with his foot (club foot, toes not facing correct way). Client stated he missed his last podiatry appointment but will call and schedule another one. I explained that since there is nothing WC can mess with (such as terminating TTDs, etc.), we are in a good spot to start making contact. Told client we would be reaching out to insurance company and doctors in the coming weeks. He said he would let me know when his next podiatry appointment is scheduled. 
__Person Making Contact:__ Bryce
__Date & Time__: March 19 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on March 19, 2024 with Michael Johnston regarding workers’ compensation case Michael-Johnston-WC-05-03-2023. The client is back at the same job full-time, with no TTDs unpaid to date. He continues to have unresolved issues with his foot, described as a club foot with the toes not facing the correct direction. He stated that he missed his last podiatry appointment but will call to schedule another one.

I explained that there is nothing the workers’ compensation program can alter at this time (such as terminating TTDs), so we are in a good position to start making contact. I told the client we would be reaching out to his insurance company and doctors in the coming weeks. He said he would let me know when his next podiatry appointment is scheduled. Contact made by Bryce.

Case: Michael-Johnston-WC-05-03-2023 involves client Michael Johnston (DOB 04/21/1978).

On April 2, 2024, an exchange concerning a certified medical records and billing request for Michael Johnston was initiated. The first message appears to have been sent by Gannon Middleton of ROI Tech, Health Information Management at UofL Health, to Sarena Tuttle, The Whaley Law Firm, and to the operating units and ROI contact points at UofL Health. The subject line of that communication was “Certified Medical Records & Billing Request - Michael Johnston DOB 04/21/1978,” and the header shows the message was received on Tuesday, April 2, 2024, at 19:06:13 +0000. The To field lists Sarena Tuttle, Patient Services, ULH HIM ROI, and ULHHIMROI@uoflhealth.org.

Later the same day, at 2:01 PM, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email with the same subject to the same recipients (including Patient Services and ULH HIM ROI). The body of her message included a SECURITY ALERT, notifying that the message is from an outside sender and advising recipients to review with caution and to report phishing if any links appeared suspicious. In the message, she wrote: “Good afternoon, Please find attached our office's request for certified medical records and billing on the above referenced client/patient. Please provide any and all billing & records for any and all departments for the dates listed. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us.” The email was signed by Sarena M. Tuttle as a Litigation Paralegal & Workers' Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and contact numbers D: (502) 357-9971 and O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104. Her email on the signature line was Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating this is her new email address.

Case: Michael-Johnston-WC-05-03-2023. Client: Michael Johnston.

On April 3, 2024, Kelly M. Vittitow, Lead Patient Services Specialist at KORT – Brooks (Oracle-26831), sent an email regarding a medical record request for Michael Johnston. In her message to Sarena Tuttle, she acknowledged the request with a brief “Thank you!” and provided her contact information and confidentiality notice. The message stated that the attached note about the Medical Records request was sent from KORT, located at 1868 West Hebron Lane, Ste. 101, Shepherdsville, KY 40165, with phone 502-955-7724 and fax 502-955-5778. The email also carried a standard confidentiality disclaimer, noting that the information may be privileged and confidential, and outlining the steps to take if the message was received in error.

Earlier that same day, at approximately 8:53 AM, Vittitow had written to Sarena Tuttle informing her that the faxed request for Michael Johnston did not include the medical release form. She instructed Sarena to refax the request with the medical release attached, and she noted that if chartswap was being used, Sarena should call the KORT Medical Records Department at 833-909-4044 to learn how to proceed with chartswap. Vittitow again provided her contact information and confidentiality language in this message, which also included the standard notice about the privileged and confidential nature of the information and instructions to notify if the message was received in error.

Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, responded on April 3, 2024 at 12:12 PM. In her reply, she thanked Vittitow for the outreach and stated that she had reuploaded the request with the authorization (auth) attached, adding that she greatly apologized for the earlier oversight. Her signature identified her as working at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. She listed her direct dial as 502-357-9971, her office number as 502-583-4022 ext. 104, and her email as Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note stating “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.” The message also contained the confidentiality disclaimer.

Together, these messages document the sequence of events for the Medical Record Request related to Michael Johnston: the initial notice that the faxed request lacked the medical release form and the instruction to refax with the release or to obtain guidance from the medical records department about using ChartSwap; the later confirmation that the request had been reuploaded with the required authorization attached; and the concluding note of appreciation from Vittitow. All communications included standard confidentiality notices regarding privileged information and instructions for recipients who were not the intended addressees.

Case: Michael-Johnston-WC-05-03-2023
Client: Michael Johnston

Narrative:

On September 30, 2024, The Whaley Law Firm’s Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager, sent an email to Dana Ballinger at Ford Motor Company regarding WC Claim# 841603 for Michael Johnston, noting the topic as Outstanding Bills. The message, which carried Sarena’s firm contact information and carried the new email address notice, was addressed to Mrs. Ballinger with Bryce Koon CC’d. In this initial email, Sarena stated: “Good morning Mrs. Ballinger, Please find attached medical billing that our client, Micheal Johnston, has been receiving. Please issue payment directly to the providers billing remittance and please forward an updated payment ledger reflecting payments made to our office. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly to discuss them in further detail.” The message also included The Whaley Law Firm’s standard signature block, showing the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and Sarena’s direct line (502) 357-9971, main line (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and the email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note reading (PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS). The body of the email included a warning line: “WARNING: This message originated outside of Ford Motor Company. Use caution when opening attachments, clicking links, or responding.”

Later that same day, around 2:29 PM (the record shows the line as “On Mon, Sep 30, 2024 at 2:29?PM Ballinger, Dana (D.) wrote:” indicating the time with a question mark), Dana Ballinger replied: “This one was paid. Attached is the EOB. The other 2 were never sent. I will call.” Ballinger’s note indicated that one of the three charges had been paid and that the EOB was attached, while the other two bills had not been sent, and she would follow up with a call.

Subsequently, at 2:30 PM (the note shows the timestamp as 14:30:43 -0400), Sarena responded to Ballinger with: “Thank you so much for following up on those. Unfortunately, the EOB was not attached.” Her reply echoed the chain of communication and requested resolution, also including her standard signature block for The Whaley Law Firm (same address and contact details as above) and again reiterating her role as Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager. The thread also includes the earlier content from Sarena’s initial message, in which she described the attached medical billing and requested payment to the providers’ remittance and a forwarded updated payment ledger reflecting payments made to her office. Throughout the correspondence, the spelling in the 9:40 AM message referred to the client as “Micheal Johnston,” a variant of the name used in that attachment.

In summary, the exchange on September 30, 2024, centered on WC Claim# 841603 for Michael Johnston, with Sarena Tuttle requesting direct payments to providers and an updated ledger, Ballinger noting that one bill had been paid with the EOB attached and that the other two had not been sent, and Sarena later reporting that the EOB had not, in fact, been attached. The communications included Sarena’s firm signature, the new email address notice, and standard contact details for both parties.

Case: Michael-Johnston-WC-05-03-2023
Client: Michael Johnston

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Spoke to client at length about IME and where case stands. He said IME went very well and that he is going to go back to one of his previous foot doctors in about a week for some kind of support re medical dispute. Explained where we stood. Told him I am waiting to see what Dr. Bloemer's report says. If he is at MMI, we will make demand and see what comes of it. If he needs further treatment (more likely) then we will have to file and see if we can't get things paid for. Client does have personal health insurance, and that is who he is using to see his old doctor. Said he would call me after his appointment to discuss. 
__Person Making Contact:__ Bryce
__Date & Time__: October 28 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Michael Johnston's workers' compensation file (Michael-Johnston-WC-05-03-2023). On October 28, 2024, Bryce made initial client contact with Michael Johnston to discuss the IME and the status of the case.

I spoke with the client at length about the independent medical examination (IME) and where the case stands. He said the IME went very well and that he plans to return to one of his previous foot doctors in about a week for some kind of support regarding the medical dispute. I explained where we stood. I am waiting to see what Dr. Bloemer's report says. If he is at Maximum Medical Improvement (MMI), we will make a demand and see what comes of it. If he needs further treatment, which is more likely, then we will have to file and see if we can't get things paid for. The client does have personal health insurance, and that is who he is using to see his old doctor. He said he would call me after his appointment to discuss.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Michael-Johnston-WC-05-03-2023
Client: Michael Johnston

This appears to be a workers' compensation case for Michael Johnston, who has a foot injury. The case involves gathering medical records and communicating with healthcare providers about the client's condition.
The most recent activity involves receiving medical records from Louisville Bone & Joint Imaging and the client contacting his previous doctor to address concerns about a report identifying his foot issues as hereditary/pre-existing. (See details), (See details)
A potential red flag is the medical report suggesting the client's foot issues are hereditary or pre-existing, which could impact the workers' compensation claim. The client has expressed frustration about this to his previous doctor. (See details)
Next steps include following up on the medical records requests sent to Louisville Bone & Joint Specialists and Dr. Mohana Arla, and monitoring for any updates from the client's previous doctor who said he would "try and help client out and make it right." (See details), (See details), (See details)
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Michael-Johnston-WC-05-03-2023. Michael Johnston is the client in a workers’ compensation matter concerning a foot injury. The case centers on gathering medical records and communicating with healthcare providers about his condition.

The most recent activity involves receiving medical records from Louisville Bone & Joint Imaging and the client contacting his previous doctor to address concerns about a report identifying his foot issues as hereditary or pre-existing.

A potential red flag is the medical report suggesting that the client’s foot issues are hereditary or pre-existing, which could impact the workers’ compensation claim. The client has expressed frustration about this to his previous doctor.

Next steps include following up on the medical records requests sent to Louisville Bone & Joint Specialists and Dr. Mohana Arla, and monitoring for any updates from the client’s previous doctor who said he would “try and help client out and make it right.”

Case: Michael-Johnston-WC-05-03-2023
Client: Michael Johnston

FILE REORGANIZATION COMPLETE - Michael Johnston Workers' Compensation Case: Completed comprehensive 5-phase file reorganization using 8-bucket directory system. Phase 1: Generated inventory of 79 files with content-only analysis (35 filenames scrambled to eliminate bias). Phase 2: Single sub-agent analyzed all documents including medical records from 6 providers (UL Hospital, UL Podiatry, KORT Physical Therapy, Kentucky Truck Plant Medical, Ford Motor Company Medical, Oasis Space Medical Equipment), litigation documents (deposition notice for 11/14/2025, IME notice for 12/18/2025, discovery request), insurance documents (UniCare disability benefits), and expenses (ChartSwap billing). Phase 3: Quality review achieved 98.7% accuracy (1 error out of 79 files) - corrected categorization of Oasis Space HIPAA authorization and records request from Client folder to Medical Records folder for consistency with other medical provider authorizations. Phase 4: Successfully executed 57 operations (55 moves/renames, 2 deletions) with zero errors, reunited all 35 PDF+MD pairs. Phase 5: Verified 100% naming convention compliance, 100% companion file integrity, and proper 8-bucket structure. Results: Client folder (29 files: intake packet, fee agreement, authorizations for DWC/SSA/employment records, client-provided documents including walker warranty, RTW emails, NCM business card, UniCare disability forms), Medical Records (60 files across 6 providers with 3-subfolder structure: Medical Records/Medical Bills/Medical Requests), Insurance/Disability/UniCare (5 files: disability benefit approval, TTD/STD benefits 5/4-5/21/2023, medical info requests, claim investigation letter), Expenses (4 files: ChartSwap invoices/receipts for KORT records $95.00), Litigation (4 files: Notice to Take Deposition dated 10/20/2025 for 11/14/2025 deposition, IME Notice dated 10/21/2025 for 12/18/2025 IME with Dr. at Arch Care Consultants, Request for Production dated 9/9/2025). Deleted 2 duplicates (duplicate deposition notice, outdated contacts.json). Key case details: Right foot fracture injury at Ford Kentucky Truck Plant on 5/3/2023, ORIF surgery 5/4/2023, treatment at UL Hospital ER, UL Podiatry (post-op follow-up, work restrictions), KORT Physical Therapy, returned to work with restrictions 6/5/2023, UniCare provided TTD/STD benefits, currently in Treatment phase with active litigation (deposition and IME scheduled). Certificate of Service dating protocol correctly applied to all litigation documents. All files now properly organized with standardized naming conventions. Case ready for deposition preparation, IME review, and settlement negotiations. Complete documentation saved to Reports/ directory.
episodes.natural_language:
The case Michael-Johnston-WC-05-03-2023 for client Michael Johnston has undergone a complete file reorganization completed under an 8-bucket directory system across five phases. Phase 1 produced an inventory of 79 files with a content-only analysis; 35 filenames were scrambled to eliminate bias. In Phase 2, a single sub-agent analyzed all documents, including medical records from six providers—UL Hospital, UL Podiatry, KORT Physical Therapy, Kentucky Truck Plant Medical, Ford Motor Company Medical, and Oasis Space Medical Equipment—as well as litigation documents (a deposition notice for November 14, 2025; an IME notice for December 18, 2025; and a discovery request), insurance documents (UniCare disability benefits), and expenses (ChartSwap billing). Phase 3’s quality review achieved 98.7% accuracy (1 error out of 79 files); the error involved the categorization of the Oasis Space HIPAA authorization and records request, which was moved from the Client folder to the Medical Records folder for consistency with other medical provider authorizations. Phase 4 successfully executed 57 operations (55 moves/renames and 2 deletions) with zero errors, and all 35 PDF+MD pairs were reunited. Phase 5 verified 100% naming convention compliance, 100% companion file integrity, and the proper 8-bucket structure.

Results were organized into clearly defined folders. The Client folder contains 29 files, including the intake packet, fee agreement, authorizations for DWC/SSA/employment records, and client-provided documents such as a walker warranty, return-to-work emails, a NCM business card, and UniCare disability forms. The Medical Records folder comprises 60 files across six providers, arranged with a 3-subfolder structure: Medical Records/Medical Bills/Medical Requests. The Insurance/Disability/UniCare folder holds five files, including a disability benefit approval, TTD/STD benefits dated 5/4–5/21/2023, medical information requests, and a claim investigation letter. The Expenses folder contains four files: ChartSwap invoices/receipts for KORT records totaling $95.00. The Litigation folder includes four files: a Notice to Take Deposition dated October 20, 2025 for the November 14, 2025 deposition, an IME Notice dated October 21, 2025 for the December 18, 2025 IME with a doctor at Arch Care Consultants, and a Request for Production dated September 9, 2025. Two duplicates were deleted: a duplicate deposition notice and outdated contacts.json. The case’s key details show a right foot fracture injury at Ford Kentucky Truck Plant on May 3, 2023, with ORIF surgery on May 4, 2023, and initial treatment at UL Hospital ER, followed by post-operative care at UL Podiatry (including work restrictions) and physical therapy at KORT Physical Therapy. The client returned to work with restrictions on June 5, 2023, UniCare provided TTD/STD benefits, and the matter is currently in the Treatment phase with active litigation, with a deposition and an IME scheduled. Certificate of Service dating protocol was correctly applied to all litigation documents. All files are now properly organized with standardized naming conventions, and the case is ready for deposition preparation, IME review, and settlement negotiations. Complete documentation has been saved to the Reports/ directory.
episodes.author: Roscoe (AI Paralegal)
